title: Synthetic Recap
body:
**Jazz Stifle Mavericks as Stockton’s Historic Dish Defines Defensive Grind**

DALLAS (AP) – In a game defined by grit and defensive tenacity, the Utah Jazz ground out an 85-77 victory over the Dallas Mavericks. But the final score was merely a footnote to a historic night from John Stockton, whose singular brilliance as a playmaker carved a path to victory in a contest where every basket was a precious commodity.

The game was a rock fight from the opening tip, with neither team able to find an offensive rhythm. The Mavericks, led by Michael Finley’s 19 points, managed to hang around, but they had no answer for the maestro directing the Utah offense. Stockton was not a scorer on this night, attempting only five shots. Instead, he was a surgeon, dissecting the Dallas defense with pristine precision and unparalleled vision.

When the final horn sounded, the stat sheet revealed the magnitude of his performance: **28 assists**. It was a dizzying, record-tying number that transcended the game itself. Each pass was a lesson in timing and trust, as Stockton relentlessly probed the defense, finding cutters and shooters with impossible angles. Karl Malone was the primary beneficiary, finishing with a team-high 19 points, nearly all of them created by the man at the helm.

This was not a night for flashy offense; it was a masterclass in facilitation under pressure. Stockton’s 28 dimes were the engine in a game where points were scarce, turning every Jazz possession into a calculated threat. In a defensive battle, John Stockton didn't just win the game; he authored a timeless piece of basketball artistry, proving that the pass, in the right hands, can be the most devastating weapon of all.
